How about enforcing Java 8 and mmaven 3.3.9 like this?
<Code>
 <plugin>
        <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
        <artifactId>maven-enforcer-plugin</artifactId>
        <version>1.4</version>
        <executions>
          <execution>
            <id>enforce-versions</id>
            <goals>
              <goal>enforce</goal>
            </goals>
            <configuration>
              <rules>
                <requireJavaVersion>
                  <version>[1.7,)</version>
                </requireJavaVersion>
                  <requireMavenVersion>
                    <version>[3.3.3,)</version>
                  </requireMavenVersion>
              </rules>
            </configuration>
          </execution>
        </executions>
      </plugin>
<Code>
@smarthi That is what it's doing, but without the enforcement for Maven, so I'll add the Maven check and push back to the branch.
+1 LGTM, we could remove the declarations for both java and maven once we include the maven-enforcer-plugin and enforce the respective versions within there.
LGTM +1

Hi @smarthi , @steveblackmon ,

Thanks for the review.
I have refactored the code to handle the following issues:

- removing of guava APIs.
- no types specified in RHS.
- Switch to TestNG in IT tests
- used `streamsDatum.getMetadata().get("id")` if it exists, enabling an stream to get a write-then-overwrite behavior when the id is already known
- supported an array of strings for host

Hi @smarthi ,

I have refactored the code to remove the `printStackTrace` method occurrence by adding `LOGGER.warn` statements.
+1 to merge

trivial change, not breaking. merging now in the interest of restoring jenkins

lazy consensus merge in 24 hours

I left one comment on introducing a RC dependency. OTT, it looks benign.  Would be nice to see if the ITs are completing (can you confirm they are?) in other news, I think we need to turn down the verbosity of Travis so this thing at least has a chance to pass builds and watch c.o.a. on integration tests.

Travis has zero chance of handling our integration tests, which do a complex dance with docker and with external services.  With some work jenkins enterprise on builds.apache.org might be able to pull it off, although it will take some hacking to set up automated attachment of the CI results to github tickets.  I do agree that it's worth trying to get there, and have noted this on https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/STREAMS-394
Ok - This PR is building for me now that I'm using juneau release 6.3.1.

jenkins passed on this version.
thanks for fixing up those asserts.
jenkins was really unhappy with this change - closing for now.

one that release is pushed to maven mirrors jenkins should pass and we'll merge this.
